Introduction

CNBLUE (Code Name Blue) is a South Korean pop-rock band formed by FNC Entertainment. They originally debuted as an indie band in Japan, releasing their first mini-album Now or Never on August 19, 2009. They later made their official Korean debut on January 14, 2010, with the breakout mini-album Bluetory, which quickly gained widespread attention and established them as a standout act in the Korean music scene.

Known for their distinctive sound blending modern rock with melodic pop elements, CNBLUE rose to fame with a series of chart-topping hits and dynamic live performances. Beyond their music, the members have also expanded their careers into acting, variety shows, and songwriting, contributing to the group’s well-rounded image and longevity in the industry.

The group originally consisted of more members. Kwon Kwangjin, who played bass during their early indie days in Japan, departed from the band shortly after their Japanese debut and was replaced by Lee Jungshin prior to the group’s Korean debut. Lee Jonghyun, who served as guitarist and vocalist, was an active member until his departure in 2019. Lee Jonghyun officially left the group in August 2019 following controversies surrounding inappropriate private messages he sent on social media. After his departure, CNBLUE continued on as a three-member band.

CNBLUE's official fandom name is BOICE, a combination of "Blue" and "Voice." It symbolizes the fans as the voice that supports CNBLUE's music and journey, forming an essential part of the band’s identity and success.
